entry.et: Middle English acounte, accompte, from Anglo-French acunte, from acunter

def.dt: :reckoning computation
:a record of debit and credit entries to cover transactions involving a particular item or a particular person or concern
:a statement of transactions during a fiscal period and the resulting balance
:a statement explaining one's conduct
:a statement or exposition of reasons, causes, or motives no satisfactory account of these phenomena
:a reason for an action :basis on that account I must refuse
:a formal business arrangement providing for regular dealings or services (as banking, advertising, or store credit) and involving the establishment and maintenance of an account
:client customer
:money deposited in a bank account and subject to withdrawal by the depositor
:value importance it's of no account to me
:esteem stood high in their account
:advantage turned her wit to good account
:careful thought :consideration have to take many things into account
:a usually mental record :track keep account of all you do
:a description of facts, conditions, or events :report narrative the newspaper account of the fire by all accounts they're well-off
:performance a straightforward account of the sonata
:with the price charged to one's account
:for the sake of :by reason of
:under no circumstances
:on one's own behalf
:at one's own risk
:by oneself :on one's own

entry.et: Middle English, from Anglo-French acunter, from a- (from Latin ad-) + cunter to count

def.dt: :to think of as :consider accounts himself lucky
:to probe into :analyze
:to furnish a justifying analysis or explanation used with for couldn't account for the loss
:to be the sole or primary factor used with for the pitcher accounted for all three putouts
:to bring about the capture, death, or destruction of something used with for accounted for two rabbits
:a business executive (as in an advertising agency) responsible for dealing with a client's account
:the balance due to a creditor on a current account
:a balance due from a debtor on a current account
:a customer's account with a creditor (as a merchant) to which the purchase of goods is charged
:a bank account against which the depositor can draw checks
:a security or commodity market account in which an agent (as a broker) is given power of attorney so as to be able to make independent decisions and buy and sell for the principal's account
:an account showing payments made to an employee in advance of actual earnings or for traveling expenses
:an account of expenses reimbursable to an employee
:the right of charging expenses to such an account
